section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In these Rules, unless the context otherwise requires—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an inquiry on a matter submitted under section 40H(1) of the Ordinance, the Society of Notaries; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an inquiry on a matter submitted under section 40H(2) of the Ordinance, the person appointed by the Chief Judge under section 3;

section.def: Tribunal Convenor (審裁組召集人) means the Tribunal Convenor appointed by the Chief Justice under section 40G(4) of the Ordinance.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Appointment of applicant
section.content: If a matter is submitted by the Chief Judge to the Tribunal Convenor under section 40H(2) of the Ordinance, the Chief Judge may appoint any person, including the Society of Notaries if it so consents, as the applicant in the subsequent inquiry.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Notice of constitution of Tribunal
section.leadIn: Within 7 days after a Tribunal has been constituted to conduct an inquiry, the clerk must by written notice inform the applicant and respondent of—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the names of the Tribunal’s members; and

section.name: s5
section.heading: Discontinuance of inquiry without hearing
section.content: If, after considering a matter submitted to the Tribunal Convenor under section 40H of the Ordinance, a Tribunal is satisfied on the face of the evidence that no case for disciplinary action is shown against the respondent, the Tribunal may make an order under section 40J(2) of the Ordinance that the inquiry be discontinued without further hearing.

subsection.leadIn: If, after considering a matter submitted to the Tribunal Convenor under section 40H of the Ordinance, a Tribunal is satisfied on the face of the evidence that a case for disciplinary action is shown against the respondent, then—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Tribunal must as soon as practicable fix the date, time and place of the first hearing of the inquiry; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by written notice inform the applicant and respondent of such hearing; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: serve on the respondent copies of relevant documents containing particulars of the conduct that is to be inquired into and particulars of any associated allegations of misconduct.

subsection.content: The period between the date of service of the notice and documents under subsection (1)(b) and the day fixed for the first hearing must not be less than 21 days.
As soon as practicable after the date, time and place of each subsequent hearing of the inquiry have been fixed, the clerk must by written notice inform the applicant and respondent.
If either the applicant or respondent fails to appear at a hearing, the Tribunal may still proceed with the inquiry if it is satisfied that a notice of hearing has been served on the absent party.
If the absent party is the applicant, the Tribunal may make an order under section 40J(2) of the Ordinance that the inquiry be discontinued without further hearing.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Representation by solicitor or counsel
section.content: The applicant and respondent may be represented at an inquiry by solicitor or counsel.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Admissibility of evidence given by affidavit

subsection.content: A Tribunal may either as to an entire inquiry or as to a particular fact proceed and act upon evidence given by affidavit.

The Tribunal may, of its own motion or on the application of the applicant or respondent, require the deponent to an affidavit to attend before the Tribunal for the purpose of giving oral evidence and of being cross-examined.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Making, service and filing of order

subsection.content: A Tribunal may make any order in relation to an inquiry on the day on which the inquiry is completed, or at a later date as the Tribunal may fix.

If the order is to be made at a later date, then as soon as practicable after the date, time and place for doing so have been fixed, the clerk must by written notice inform the applicant and respondent.
Within 4 days after the date of making the order, the clerk must serve the order on the applicant and respondent.
Within 14 days after the date of making the order, the clerk must file the order in accordance with sections 40J(3) and 40L(2) of the Ordinance.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Withdrawal of proceedings
section.content: Unless a Tribunal directs otherwise, no proceedings before it may be withdrawn once a notice of the first hearing of the inquiry has been served under section 6(1)(b).

section.name: s12
section.heading: Adjournments
section.content: A Tribunal may, of its own motion or on the application of the applicant or respondent, adjourn a hearing on such terms as to costs or otherwise as the Tribunal considers appropriate.

subsection.content: The proceedings of the Tribunal must be recorded by shorthand notes or by sound recording.
The applicant and respondent to the proceedings may inspect and take copies of the record on payment of reasonable charges to the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: Service of a notice or document under these Rules may be effected personally or by registered post addressed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a Tribunal, to the clerk at the Tribunal’s address for service referred to in section 4(c);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a respondent—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to the respondent’s usual place of residence or business in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the address is unknown, to the respondent’s last known place of residence or business in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any other case, to the last known place of residence or business in Hong Kong of the person to be served.

subsection.content: A Tribunal may make an order for substituted service of a notice or document if the Tribunal considers it appropriate to do so.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Extension or abridgement of time
section.content: Where a Tribunal has specified a time limit within which a person is required to do anything under these Rules, the Tribunal may extend or abridge such time limit.

subsection.leadIn: Unless a Tribunal otherwise orders, all documents and exhibits produced, used or made in connection with any proceedings under these Rules must be retained by the Tribunal or the clerk—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: until the time for an appeal under section 40M of the Ordinance has expired; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if an appeal is lodged, until the appeal is heard or otherwise disposed of,

subsection.continued: and thereafter must be deposited with the Secretary for safe keeping.

subsection.content: The Secretary must retain the documents and exhibits for a period of not less than 3 years after the date of their receipt. During that period, no person may have access to the documents or exhibits without the Tribunal Convenor’s consent.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Procedure and rules of evidence
section.content: Subject to the Ordinance and these Rules, a Tribunal may determine its own procedure and rules of evidence.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Summons
section.content: The form of a summons issued under section 40K(1) of the Ordinance must be in accordance with the form prescribed in the Schedule.
